p: Through gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS) analysis, the EO extracted from the roots of C. acaulis was characterised and the data obtained were in accordance with the work of Benelli et al. [ 56]. Seven compounds were identified, among which carlina oxide was the predominant EO component, comprising 94.6% of the relative content. Other compounds were identified, such as the aromatic benzaldehyde (3.1%) and the sesquiterpene ar-curcumene (0.4%) ( Figure 1). Acetophenone, benzyl methyl ketone, camphor, and carvone were detected at trace levels.
